reviewText: While dining at my local pharmacy the other day (we still have a working lunch counter) I was perusing through their DVDs while waiting for my food to come when I came across this title for the reduced price of $3.99. Ever since the Johnny Depp LONE RANGER had come out I have wanted to see Clayton Moore's 2 feature films made in 1956 and 1958 right as the long running TV show was ending. I don't remember seeing these in the theater (I was 4 and 6 respectively when they first came out so I may have) but I do remember the series. I even had a LONE RANGER lunchbox and a plastic LR complete with a plastic Silver. My initial rental/streaming attempts were stymied so I moved on to other things when this DVD suddenly appeared. It was the only copy left and the fact that the price had been reduced indicated that it hadn't moved and they were trying to unload it. I was happy to oblige.Both of these films have been available for years in cheap transfers first on VHS and then on DVD. VCI, a quality purveyor of copyright expired films, released them both on VHS and then DVD before losing the rights to them once the new LONE RANGER was in the works. To my knowledge, they remain the gold standard as far as print quality is concerned but this disc from Classic Media, a division of Vivendi, is remarkably good especially when you consider the retail price. Both prints have vivid colors although they are occasionally a little over saturated and a little dark. They also show very little print damage unlike so many other copies out there. The volume for both is a little low indicating that they are second generation dupes but that is easy to correct. In fact, considering what I paid, both prints turned out to be a lot better than I expected which really increased my enjoyment. They are even enhanced for widescreen TVs but that was not the big surprise.The big surprise came in the content of both films. I remember Tonto being more than just a sidekick in the TV series but in these two films he really comes into his own. In the first film The Lone Ranger and Tonto come to the aid of a tribe of Indians who are being forced off their lands by a greedy land baron. In the second they try and solve the murder of local Indians by a group of hooded outlaws. Both films are remarkably pro-Native American for the time and Tonto is given a major role in LOST CITY OF GOLD. I'm sure that Jay Silverheels had major input into the scripts of both of these. Another plus is the chance to see Clayton Moore without his mask as he poses as an old prospector in the first one and a Southern gentleman in the second. I'm glad that these films hold up well today unlike the old TV show which was limited by the restrictions imposed on 1950s television. If you've never seen the original LONE RANGER and are curious, then these two movies show him and Tonto off at their very best.

reviewText: This DVD is a double feature which includes the first two Lone Ranger movies with Clayton Moore...the real Lone Ranger  These movies are so much better than the two "new" Lone Ranger films, both of which in my view were horrible.  There is only one Lone Ranger and one Tonto, and they are on this DVD.  Buy it, Kemo Sabe.

reviewText: If you remember and liked the show, here's your chance to see a longer story, larger budget version in color with all the great scenery. The DVD quality is quite good for the age and the cost of this offering. Two movies, both are entertaining, I remember seeing them on a Saturday theater offering, in a small Upper Michigan town, and now I can share this with the Grandkids. If we don't show them that there once was "good" entertainment, who will?
summary: The opportunity to see the Lone Ranger in color

reviewText: This DVD features "The Lone Ranger" and "The Lone Ranger and The Lost City of Gold" - two colour feature length movies from 1956 and 1958 respectively after the famous TV series ended. Now that Clayton Moore and Jay Silverheels have hit middle-age, you can see they're getting a little older for their roles here. But that doesn't take away from the enjoyment and excitement of watching the classic "Lone Ranger" in action and in colour. I found the first feature was the better of the two, having more action and stronger villains. It was also interesting to see them actually put a bit of money into the production of these films. Sometimes you could really see them cutting corners on the original TV series.In terms of the DVD itself, there are no extras or special features such as subtitles unfortunately. Then again this is clearly designed to be a budget priced DVD. The prints are generally good, although the colours are a little dull or muted at times. "The Lone Ranger" is probably a B grade image. It's not razor sharp and there's some occasional speckling and the odd line through much of the early part of the film. The print does show its age and I was a little surprised by that. But it's still more than watchable and the damage is not really distracting. However, I was particularly disappointed to read afterwards that these were widescreen features so I'm assuming Classic Media has cropped these somehow. With "The Lone Ranger" there were a few brief vista scenes where the left and right sides of the screen seemed fuzzy like they've compressed the picture a bit.I didn't notice as much print damage to "The Lone Ranger and The Lost City of Gold." It would probably rate a B+ but again it's not a restoration-type image. I'm assuming these are the best prints out there but the VCI releases that came out a few years ago might be comparable in image. They apparently have some special features like interviews with Clayton Moore's daughter.All in all, I'd give this release a B. But it's hard not to be a little disappointed seeing all the time and effort that Classic Media put into their Lone Ranger 75th Anniversary Collector's Edition a couple of years back. That set was simply gorgeous! Hopefully Classic Media still has plans to release the remaining seasons of the classic "Lone Ranger" with that same degree of quality and care.
summary: Lone Ranger DVD Not Always As Good As Gold
